instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: In a vast realm of undulating landscapes, where peaks embraced the sky and valleys carved the earth, there reigned a king whose palace perched atop one of these towering mountains. It was a structure of splendor and magnificence, a fitting abode for royalty. Born within these regal walls was Princess Irene, a child of delicate beginnings. Shortly after her arrival into the world, Irene, whose mother's health was frail, was entrusted to the pastoral care of villagers. They dwelled in a stately dwelling, a hybrid of castle and country home, nestled midway up the slope of a neighboring mountain.\n
output: There was once a little princess whose father was king over a great country full of mountains and valleys. His palace was built upon one of the mountains, and was very grand and beautiful. The princess, whose name was Irene, was born there, but she was sent soon after her birth, because her mother was not very strong, to be brought up by country people in a large house, half castle, half farmhouse, on the side of another mountain, about half-way between its base and its peak.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Princess Irene was a charming and delicate child. As my narrative unfolds, she was about eight years old, rapidly approaching the cusp of maturity. Her visage radiated beauty, framed by a pair of eyes that mirrored the nocturnal heavens—dark and deep, each flecked with a solitary, shimmering star. These celestial eyes seemed almost aware of their origin, frequently gazing skyward. Above her, the nursery ceiling was painted a stellar blue, dotted with artificial stars striving to mimic the celestial dome. Yet, despite this crafted canopy, it is doubtful that Princess Irene ever truly witnessed the natural splendor of a starry sky, a fact tied to a crucial reason that merits immediate disclosure.\n
output: The princess was a sweet little creature, and at the time my story begins was about eight years old, I think, but she got older very fast. Her face was fair and pretty, with eyes like two bits of night sky, each with a star dissolved in the blue. Those eyes you would have thought must have known they came from there, so often were they turned up in that direction. The ceiling of her nursery was blue, with stars in it, as like the sky as they could make it. But I doubt if ever she saw the real sky with the stars in it, for a reason which I had better mention at once.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Beneath the rugged expanse of these mountains lay a hidden world of vast hollows; expansive caverns intertwined with serpentine passages, some veins filled with murmuring streams, others aglow with a kaleidoscope of colors when illuminated. These subterranean marvels might have remained largely unexplored, were it not for the mines etched deep within the mountain's heart. Miners, in pursuit of the rich ores cradled in the rock, carved extensive galleries and tunnels. During their excavations, they frequently breached these natural chambers. A select few of these caverns even opened distantly onto mountain flanks or into secluded ravines.\n
output: These mountains were full of hollow places underneath; huge caverns, and winding ways, some with water running through them, and some shining with all colours of the rainbow when a light was taken in. There would not have been much known about them, had there not been mines there, great deep pits, with long galleries and passages running off from them, which had been dug to get at the ore of which the mountains were full. In the course of digging, the miners came upon many of these natural caverns. A few of them had far-off openings out on the side of a mountain, or into a ravine.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Beneath the earth's surface, in shadowy caverns, dwelled enigmatic beings, variously named gnomes, kobolds, or goblins by the local populace. Legends whispered that they once lived among the surface dwellers, indistinguishable from other folk. However, driven underground by oppressive taxes, stringent laws, or harsh treatment from the king, they vanished from above ground society. Opting not to flee to foreign lands, they sought sanctuary in the labyrinthine caves below, emerging only under the veil of night. Rarely seen, these creatures congregated in the most secluded mountainous areas, seldom revealing themselves. Those who glimpsed them spoke of their transformation over generations into figures of either grotesque horror or bizarre whimsy, far surpassing any wild fantasy depicted in art or literature. Yet, some speculated these witnesses might have confused the goblins' animal allies for the goblins themselves. Despite their grotesque forms, the goblins retained a semblance of humanity, gaining in cunning and intelligence what they lost in beauty. Mischievously inclined, they delighted in vexing the surface dwellers, particularly the descendants of the king responsible for their plight. Over time, the goblins established their own monarchy and government, focused largely on crafting nuisances for their aboveground neighbors. This explains why Princess Irene, growing up amidst such threats, never witnessed the starlit sky—her guardians, wary of goblin mischief, kept her safely indoors during the night.\n
output: Now in these subterranean caverns lived a strange race of beings, called by some gnomes, by some kobolds, by some goblins. There was a legend current in the country that at one time they lived above ground, and were very like other people. But for some reason or other, concerning which there were different legendary theories, the king had laid what they thought too severe taxes upon them, or had required observances of them they did not like, or had begun to treat them with more severity, in some way or other, and impose stricter laws; and the consequence was that they had all disappeared from the face of the country. According to the legend, however, instead of going to some other country, they had all taken refuge in the subterranean caverns, whence they never came out but at night, and then seldom showed themselves in any numbers, and never to many people at once. It was only in the least frequented and most difficult parts of the mountains that they were said to gather even at night in the open air. Those who had caught sight of any of them said that they had greatly altered in the course of generations; and no wonder, seeing they lived away from the sun, in cold and wet and dark places. They were now, not ordinarily ugly, but either absolutely hideous, or ludicrously grotesque both in face and form. There was no invention, they said, of the most lawless imagination expressed by pen or pencil, that could surpass the extravagance of their appearance. But I suspect those who said so had mistaken some of their animal companions for the goblins themselves--of which more by and by. The goblins themselves were not so far removed from the human as such a description would imply. And as they grew misshapen in body they had grown in knowledge and cleverness, and now were able to do things no mortal could see the possibility of. But as they grew in cunning, they grew in mischief, and their great delight was in every way they could think of to annoy the people who lived in the open-air storey above them. They had enough of affection left for each other to preserve them from being absolutely cruel for cruelty's sake to those that came in their way; but still they so heartily cherished the ancestral grudge against those who occupied their former possessions and especially against the descendants of the king who had caused their expulsion, that they sought every opportunity of tormenting them in ways that were as odd as their inventors; and although dwarfed and misshapen, they had strength equal to their cunning. In the process of time they had got a king and a government of their own, whose chief business, beyond their own simple affairs, was to devise trouble for their neighbours. It will now be pretty evident why the little princess had never seen the sky at night. They were much too afraid of the goblins to let her out of the house then, even in company with ever so many attendants; and they had good reason, as we shall see by and by.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: As previously mentioned, Princess Irene was nearing the age of eight at the outset of this tale. Here begins our story.\n
output: I have said the Princess Irene was about eight years old when my story begins. And this is how it begins.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: On a particularly sodden day, with the mountain enveloped in a shroud of mist that coalesced into persistent raindrops, the deluge drenched the roofs of the grand, aged manor. Water cascaded from the eaves, forming a curtain of droplets encircling the building. Naturally, such conditions precluded any outdoor excursions for Princess Irene.\n
output: One very wet day, when the mountain was covered with mist which was constantly gathering itself together into raindrops, and pouring down on the roofs of the great old house, whence it fell in a fringe of water from the eaves all round about it, the princess could not of course go out.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Exhaustion overcame Princess Irene, to such an extent that even her vast array of toys failed to entertain her. The sheer quantity and variety of her toys were remarkable, and had there been time, detailing even a fraction of them would surely astonish you. However, possessing these toys and merely hearing of them are entirely different experiences; one cannot grow weary of something unattained. It was a captivating scene, nonetheless—Princess Irene seated in her nursery, under a ceiling painted like the sky, surrounded by a sprawling array of toys laid out on a large table.\n
output: She got very tired, so tired that even her toys could no longer amuse her. You would wonder at that if I had time to describe to you one half of the toys she had. But then, you wouldn't have the toys themselves, and that makes all the difference: you can't get tired of a thing before you have it. It was a picture, though, worth seeing--the princess sitting in the nursery with the sky ceiling over her head, at a great table covered with her toys.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Should an artist endeavor to capture this scene, I would caution him against including the toys in his depiction. Their complexity is such that even attempting to describe them is daunting, and replicating them in a drawing might be an even greater challenge. It is best left unattempted. However, the artist's talent could brilliantly render Princess Irene herself, portrayed as she was: slumped back into her chair, head drooping, hands resting listlessly in her lap, the very image of misery. She expressed a wish only for the freedom to roam outside, to be drenched by the rain, perhaps catch a cold severe enough to warrant bedrest and warm gruel.\n
output: If the artist would like to draw this, I should advise him not to meddle with the toys. I am afraid of attempting to describe them, and I think he had better not try to draw them. He had better not. He can do a thousand things I can't, but I don't think he could draw those toys. No man could better make the princess herself than he could, though--leaning with her back bowed into the back of the chair, her head hanging down, and her hands in her lap, very miserable as she would say herself, not even knowing what she would like, except it were to go out and get thoroughly wet, and catch a particularly nice cold, and have to go to bed and take gruel.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Moments after envisioning Princess Irene in her forlorn state, picture her nurse quietly exiting the room.\n
output: The next moment after you see her sitting there, her nurse goes out of the room.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: This departure introduces a subtle shift in the atmosphere, stirring Princess Irene from her drowsy state. She glances around, then swiftly slides off her chair and darts through a doorway—different from the one her nurse used. She approaches an ancient staircase crafted from worm-eaten oak that exudes an air of long disuse. Previously, Irene had ventured up just six of these steps, but the dreary day now fuels her curiosity to explore further, compelling her to discover what lies at the staircase's summit.\n
output: Even that is a change, and the princess wakes up a little, and looks about her. Then she tumbles off her chair and runs out of the door, not the same door the nurse went out of, but one which opened at the foot of a curious old stair of worm-eaten oak, which looked as if never anyone had set foot upon it. She had once before been up six steps, and that was sufficient reason, in such a day, for trying to find out what was at the top of it.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Princess Irene ascended tirelessly, her small feet carrying her higher than she felt she had ever climbed before, until she reached the top of the third flight of stairs. There, she emerged onto a landing that served as the entryway to a lengthy corridor. This passageway, lined with numerous doors on both sides, sparked little interest in her to explore any single one. Instead, she continued her sprint to the far end, where she encountered another corridor, similarly adorned with an array of doors.\n
output: Up and up she ran--such a long way it seemed to her!--until she came to the top of the third flight. There she found the landing was the end of a long passage. Into this she ran. It was full of doors on each side. There were so many that she did not care to open any, but ran on to the end, where she turned into another passage, also full of doors.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: After making two more turns, Princess Irene's environment remained unchanged, presenting her with nothing but door after door. The oppressive silence and the sheer number of unexplored, seemingly empty rooms began to unsettle her deeply. The rain's persistent drumming on the roof only heightened the eerie atmosphere. In a burst of fear, she whirled around and dashed back toward what she hoped would be the stairs leading to her secure nursery. Her small feet pattered urgently against the floor, the sound mingling with the rain's chorus. However, despite her conviction, she had become hopelessly disoriented much earlier. Being lost in location did not necessarily mean she was lost in purpose, though.\n
output: When she had turned twice more, and still saw doors and only doors about her, she began to get frightened. It was so silent! And all those doors must hide rooms with nobody in them! That was dreadful. Also the rain made a great trampling noise on the roof. She turned and started at full speed, her little footsteps echoing through the sounds of the rain--back for the stairs and her safe nursery. So she thought, but she had lost herself long ago. It doesn't follow that she was lost, because she had lost herself, though.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: After running a considerable distance and making multiple turns, Princess Irene's initial unease transformed into palpable fear. It wasn't long before she realized she had completely lost her way back to safety. Surrounded by endless rooms with no sign of the stairs, her heart raced as rapidly as her feet moved, and tears began to well in her throat. Yet, her overwhelming fear and determination kept her from crying for a while. Eventually, as all hope seemed to vanish, faced with nothing but relentless passageways and doors, her resilience crumbled. She collapsed to the floor in despair, surrendering to a torrent of loud, sobbing cries.\n
output: She ran for some distance, turned several times, and then began to be afraid. Very soon she was sure that she had lost the way back. Rooms everywhere, and no stair! Her little heart beat as fast as her little feet ran, and a lump of tears was growing in her throat. But she was too eager and perhaps too frightened to cry for some time. At last her hope failed her. Nothing but passages and doors everywhere! She threw herself on the floor, and burst into a wailing cry broken by sobs.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Her tears did not last long, reflecting the courage you'd expect from a young princess. After allowing herself the release of a good cry, Irene stood up and dusted off her frock, which was coated in an ancient layer of dust. She then wiped her eyes with her hands, lacking a handkerchief, much like many other little girls. Determined to handle the situation with royal wisdom, she decided to methodically explore the corridors in search of the staircase. Despite her systematic approach, success eluded her. She inadvertently retraced her steps multiple times, unable to distinguish one passage from another, as each looked exactly like the last.\n
output: She did not cry long, however, for she was as brave as could be expected of a princess of her age. After a good cry, she got up, and brushed the dust from her frock. Oh, what old dust it was! Then she wiped her eyes with her hands, for princesses don't always have their handkerchiefs in their pockets, any more than some other little girls I know of. Next, like a true princess, she resolved on going wisely to work to find her way back: she would walk through the passages, and look in every direction for the stair. This she did, but without success. She went over the same ground again and again without knowing it, for the passages and doors were all alike.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Finally, in a remote corner, through a door slightly ajar, Princess Irene glimpsed a staircase. However, it was not the descent she had hoped for; this stairway ascended further. Despite her fear, curiosity overcame her, compelling her to discover where this upward path might lead. The stair was so narrow and steep that she found herself climbing more like an animal, on both hands and feet, than as a princess.\n
output: At last, in a corner, through a half-open door, she did see a stair. But alas! it went the wrong way: instead of going down, it went up. Frightened as she was, however, she could not help wishing to see where yet further the stair could lead. It was very narrow, and so steep that she went on like a four-legged creature on her hands and feet.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'Where have you wandered off to, Princess?' the nurse inquired, embracing her tightly. 'It was quite worrisome for you to disappear for so long. I started to fear—' She paused abruptly, catching herself before saying more.\n
output: 'Why, where can you have been, princess?' asked the nurse, taking her in her arms. 'It's very unkind of you to hide away so long. I began to be afraid--' Here she checked herself.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'What frightened you, Nursie?' inquired the princess, her curiosity piqued.\n
output: 'What were you afraid of, nursie?' asked the princess.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'Never mind,' she replied dismissively. 'Maybe I'll share it with you on another day. But now, please tell me where you've been.'\n
output: 'Never mind,' she answered. 'Perhaps I will tell you another day. Now tell me where you have been.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'I ventured quite far up to visit my very ancient, enormous grandmother,' declared the princess.\n
output: 'I've been up a long way to see my very great, huge, old grandmother,' said the princess.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'What do you mean by that?' asked the nurse, suspecting the princess was joking.\n
output: 'What do you mean by that?' asked the nurse, who thought she was making fun.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'I truly went far, climbing up and up to visit my GREAT grandmother. Oh, Nursie, you can't imagine the wonderful mother of grandmothers I have upstairs. She's an incredibly old lady, with stunning white hair—just as white as my silver cup. Now that I reflect on it, her hair must surely be silver,' explained the princess with a sense of awe.\n
output: 'I mean that I've been a long way up and up to see My GREAT grandmother. Ah, nursie, you don't know what a beautiful mother of grandmothers I've got upstairs. She is such an old lady, with such lovely white hair--as white as my silver cup. Now, when I think of it, I think her hair must be silver.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'What nonsense you're speaking, princess!' exclaimed the nurse.\n
output: 'What nonsense you are talking, princess!' said the nurse.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'I'm not talking nonsense,' retorted Irene, feeling slightly offended. 'I'll tell you everything about her. She's much taller than you, and much prettier too.'\n
output: 'I'm not talking nonsense,' returned Irene, rather offended. 'I will tell you all about her. She's much taller than you, and much prettier.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'Oh, I dare say!' remarked the nurse, skeptically.\n
output: 'Oh, I dare say!' remarked the nurse.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'And she survives on pigeons' eggs.' 'Most likely,' the nurse responded dryly. 'And she spends her days in an empty room, constantly spinning.' 'Not a doubt of it,' the nurse affirmed. 'And she stores her crown in her bedroom.' 'Of course—quite the right place for a crown. I bet she even wears it to bed,' the nurse added with a hint of sarcasm.\n
output: 'And she lives upon pigeons' eggs.' 'Most likely,' said the nurse. 'And she sits in an empty room, spin-spinning all day long.' 'Not a doubt of it,' said the nurse. 'And she keeps her crown in her bedroom.' 'Of course--quite the proper place to keep her crown in. She wears it in bed, I'll be bound.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'She didn't mention that. And I don't believe she does. Wearing a crown to bed wouldn't be comfortable, would it? My papa doesn't use his crown as a night-cap, right, Nursie?' 'I've never asked him. But I dare say he might,' the nurse replied with playful conjecture.\n
output: 'She didn't say that. And I don't think she does. That wouldn't be comfortable--would it? I don't think my papa wears his crown for a night-cap. Does he, nursie?' 'I never asked him. I dare say he does.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'And she's been there ever since I came here—ever so many years.' 'Anybody could have told you that,' responded the nurse, her tone indicating skepticism as she doubted the truth of Irene's statements.\n
output: 'And she's been there ever since I came here--ever so many years.' 'Anybody could have told you that,' said the nurse, who did not believe a word Irene was saying.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'Why wasn't I informed earlier?' 'It wasn't essential. You were capable of deducing it independently.'\n
output: 'Why didn't you tell me, then?' 'There was no necessity. You could make it all up for yourself.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'You doubt my word?' the princess cried out, both shocked and upset, a reaction that was fully justified.\n
output: 'You don't believe me, then!' exclaimed the princess, astonished and angry, as she well might be.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'Did you really think I would take your words for truth, princess?' the nurse inquired with a chill in her voice. 'Princesses often spin tales, yet you are the first I've encountered who anticipated her stories would be accepted as fact,' she noted, observing the child's unusual sincerity.\n
output: 'Did you expect me to believe you, princess?' asked the nurse coldly. 'I know princesses are in the habit of telling make-believes, but you are the first I ever heard of who expected to have them believed,' she added, seeing that the child was strangely in earnest.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: The princess erupted in a flood of tears.\n
output: The princess burst into tears.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'I must admit,' the nurse said, clearly annoyed by her tears, 'it's quite unbecoming of a princess to fabricate tales and assume they'll be trusted simply because she holds a title.'\n
output: 'Well, I must say,' remarked the nurse, now thoroughly vexed with her for crying, 'it is not at all becoming in a princess to tell stories and expect to be believed just because she is a princess.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'But I assure you, it's the truth,' she insisted. 'You must have dreamt it, then, child.' 'No, it wasn't a dream. I went upstairs, got lost, and if not for the beautiful lady, I would have remained lost.'\n
output: 'But it's quite true, I tell you.' 'You've dreamt it, then, child.' 'No, I didn't dream it. I went upstairs, and I lost myself, and if I hadn't found the beautiful lady, I should never have found myself.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'Oh, likely story!' 'Come with me then, and see for yourself if I'm lying.' 'Indeed, I have other tasks at hand. It's time for your dinner, and I will entertain no more of this foolishness.'\n
output: 'Oh, I dare say!' 'Well, you just come up with me, and see if I'm not telling the truth.' 'Indeed I have other work to do. It's your dinnertime, and I won't have any more such nonsense.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: The princess dried her eyes, her face flushing so warmly that her tears soon evaporated. She seated herself for dinner but barely touched her food. Being disbelieved is particularly disagreeable to princesses, as a true princess cannot utter falsehoods. Consequently, she remained silent for the entire afternoon. She responded only when the nurse addressed her, maintaining her courtesy, for a true princess is never impolite—even when justified in feeling aggrieved.\n
output: The princess wiped her eyes, and her face grew so hot that they were soon quite dry. She sat down to her dinner, but ate next to nothing. Not to be believed does not at all agree with princesses: for a real princess cannot tell a lie. So all the afternoon she did not speak a word. Only when the nurse spoke to her, she answered her, for a real princess is never rude--even when she does well to be offended.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Naturally, the nurse felt uneasy—not because she believed any part of Irene's story, but because she cherished her deeply and regretted her own irritability. She attributed the princess's distress to her own sharpness, unaware that Irene was genuinely pained by not being believed. As the evening progressed, it became increasingly evident from Irene's every movement and expression that, despite her attempts to engage with her toys, her heart was too aggrieved to find joy in them, which only intensified the nurse's discomfort.\n
output: Of course the nurse was not comfortable in her mind--not that she suspected the least truth in Irene's story, but that she loved her dearly, and was vexed with herself for having been cross to her. She thought her crossness was the cause of the princess's unhappiness, and had no idea that she was really and deeply hurt at not being believed. But, as it became more and more plain during the evening in her every motion and look, that, although she tried to amuse herself with her toys, her heart was too vexed and troubled to enjoy them, her nurse's discomfort grew and grew.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: At bedtime, the nurse undressed the princess and tucked her into bed, but instead of offering her usual little kiss, the child turned away, lying motionless. This complete rejection finally broke the nurse's composure, prompting her to weep. Hearing the initial sobs of her nurse, the princess turned back to offer a kiss as she normally would. However, the nurse, overwhelmed and with her handkerchief covering her eyes, missed this gesture of reconciliation.\n
output: When bedtime came, she undressed and laid her down, but the child, instead of holding up her little mouth to be kissed, turned away from her and lay still. Then nursie's heart gave way altogether, and she began to cry. At the sound of her first sob the princess turned again, and held her face to kiss her as usual. But the nurse had her handkerchief to her eyes, and did not see the movement.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'Nursie,' implored the princess, 'why can't you believe me?' 'I just can't,' replied the nurse, her frustration flaring up once more.\n
output: 'Nursie,' said the princess, 'why won't you believe me?' 'Because I can't believe you,' said the nurse, getting angry again.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'Ah, then you're powerless to change it,' Irene conceded, 'and I won't hold it against you any longer. I'll give you a kiss and go to sleep.'\n
output: 'Ah! then, you can't help it,' said Irene, 'and I will not be vexed with you any more. I will give you a kiss and go to sleep.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'You little angel!' exclaimed the nurse, as she lifted the princess from her bed and carried her around the room, showering her with kisses and embraces.\n
output: 'You little angel!' cried the nurse, and caught her out of bed, and walked about the room with her in her arms, kissing and hugging her.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'Will you come with me to meet my beloved old great-grandmother?' asked the princess, gently placing her back in bed.\n
output: 'You will let me take you to see my dear old great big grandmother, won't you?' said the princess, as she laid her down again.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'And you won't call me ugly anymore, will you, princess?' 'Nursie, I never said you were ugly. How could you think that?'\n
output: 'And you won't say I'm ugly, any more--will you, princess?' 'Nursie, I never said you were ugly. What can you mean?'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'Well, if you didn't say it, you certainly implied it.' 'Truly, I never did.'\n
output: 'Well, if you didn't say it, you meant it.' 'Indeed, I never did.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'You claimed I wasn't as pretty as that--' 'As my lovely grandmother—yes, that I did say; and I'll say it once more, because it's absolutely true.'\n
output: 'You said I wasn't so pretty as that--' 'As my beautiful grandmother--yes, I did say that; and I say it again, for it's quite true.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'Then I must say you are being harsh!' exclaimed the nurse, bringing her handkerchief to her eyes once more.\n
output: 'Then I do think you are unkind!' said the nurse, and put her handkerchief to her eyes again.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'Nursie, dear, not everyone can be as beautiful as everyone else, you know. You're quite attractive, but if you were as beautiful as my grandmother--'\n
output: 'Nursie, dear, everybody can't be as beautiful as every other body, you know. You are very nice-looking, but if you had been as beautiful as my grandmother--'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'Enough about your grandmother!' exclaimed the nurse.\n
output: 'Bother your grandmother!' said the nurse.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'Nurse, that was quite disrespectful. I shouldn't speak to you until you can act more appropriately.'\n
output: 'Nurse, that's very rude. You are not fit to be spoken to till you can behave better.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'I truly apologize, princess,' she said, her voice still carrying a hint of offense. Yet the princess chose to overlook the tone and focused solely on the apology.\n
output: 'I'm sure I beg your pardon, princess,' she said, though still in an offended tone. But the princess let the tone pass, and heeded only the words.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'You won't repeat that, I'm certain,' she responded, facing her nurse once again. 'I was merely going to suggest that if you had been twice as charming as you are, some king might have taken you for his queen. Then, what would have become of me?'\n
output: 'You won't say it again, I am sure,' she answered, once more turning towards her nurse. 'I was only going to say that if you had been twice as nice-looking as you are, some king or other would have married you, and then what would have become of me?'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'You truly are an angel!' the nurse exclaimed once more, wrapping her in another warm embrace. 'Now,' Irene pressed on, 'you must visit my grandmother with me--will you?' 'I'll accompany you wherever you wish, my dear cherub,' the nurse replied; and within moments, the exhausted little princess was soundly asleep.\n

He had not kept the position for one minute before he heard something which made him sharpen his ears. It sounded like a voice inside the rock. After a while he heard it again.
