output: 'Well, I never knew so much before!' remarked a fourth voice. 'Your knowledge is not universal quite yet,' said the father. 'You were only fifty last month. Mind you see to the bed and bedding. As soon as we've finished our supper, we'll be up and going. Ha! ha! ha!' 'What are you laughing at, husband?' 'I'm laughing to think what a mess the miners will find themselves in--somewhere before this day ten years.' 'Why, what do you mean?' 'Oh, nothing.' 'Oh, yes, you do mean something. You always do mean something.' 'It's more than you do, then, wife.' 'That may be; but it's not more than I find out, you know.' 'Ha! ha! You're a sharp one. What a mother you've got, Helfer!' 'Yes, father.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'Well, I guess I should spill the beans. They're all gathered at the palace tonight to discuss it, and once we're clear of this vulnerable spot, I'm heading there to find out which night they settle on. I'd love to witness that young troublemaker over there, writhing in the throes of--' He lowered his voice to a murmur, leaving Curdie to discern only a grumble. The grumble continued in a deep bass for quite some time, as incomprehensible as if the goblin's tongue had been a sausage; and it wasn't until his wife spoke again that it returned to its previous tone.\n
output: 'Well, I suppose I must tell you. They're all at the palace consulting about it tonight; and as soon as we've got away from this thin place I'm going there to hear what night they fix upon. I should like to see that young ruffian there on the other side, struggling in the agonies of--' He dropped his voice so low that Curdie could hear only a growl. The growl went on in the low bass for a good while, as inarticulate as if the goblin's tongue had been a sausage; and it was not until his wife spoke again that it rose to its former pitch.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'But what's our plan while you're at the palace?' she inquired. 'I'll ensure your safety in the new residence I've been excavating for the past two months. Podge, you keep an eye on the table and chairs. I entrust them to your supervision. The table boasts seven legs--each chair, three. I'll need them all from you.'\n
output: 'But what shall we do when you are at the palace?' she asked. 'I will see you safe in the new house I've been digging for you for the last two months. Podge, you mind the table and chairs. I commit them to your care. The table has seven legs--each chair three. I shall require them all at your hands.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Following this, a muddled discussion ensued regarding the relocation of various household items; Curdie caught no further significant details. He now understood at least one reason behind the incessant noise of goblin tools at night: they were constructing new residences as safe havens in case miners threatened to breach their current dwellings. However, he gleaned two more crucial insights: impending disaster loomed over the miners, and he discovered a vulnerability in goblins—a weakness in their feet, previously unknown to him.\n
output: After this arose a confused conversation about the various household goods and their transport; and Curdie heard nothing more that was of any importance. He now knew at least one of the reasons for the constant sound of the goblin hammers and pickaxes at night. They were making new houses for themselves, to which they might retreat when the miners should threaten to break into their dwellings. But he had learned two things of far greater importance. The first was, that some grievous calamity was preparing, and almost ready to fall upon the heads of the miners; the second was--the one weak point of a goblin's body; he had not known that their feet were so tender as he had now reason to suspect.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: It was rumored that goblins lacked toes, but Curdie hadn't had a chance to examine them closely in the perpetual dusk in which they roamed. Similarly, the assertion that they lacked fingers remained unverified. One miner, more educated than the rest, theorized that this might have been humanity's original state, and that toes and fingers developed through education and craftsmanship. Curdie once heard his father jestingly support this notion, citing baby gloves and stockings as potential vestiges of this primitive condition.\n
output: He had heard it said that they had no toes: he had never had opportunity of inspecting them closely enough, in the dusk in which they always appeared, to satisfy himself whether it was a correct report. Indeed, he had not been able even to satisfy himself as to whether they had no fingers, although that also was commonly said to be the fact. One of the miners, indeed, who had had more schooling than the rest, was wont to argue that such must have been the primordial condition of humanity, and that education and handicraft had developed both toes and fingers--with which proposition Curdie had once heard his father sarcastically agree, alleging in support of it the probability that babies' gloves were a traditional remnant of the old state of things; while the stockings of all ages, no regard being paid in them to the toes, pointed in the same direction.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Curdie's immediate task was to uncover the goblins' nefarious plan. While he was familiar with the gangs and natural passages in the mined area of the mountain, he had no knowledge of the location of the goblin king's palace. If he did, he would have embarked on the mission to uncover their scheme without delay. He presumed that the palace lay in a distant part of the mountain, not yet accessible from the mine. However, he suspected that a passage connecting the two areas was nearing completion, given the thin barrier that currently separated them.\n
output: What he had to do in the meantime, however, was to discover, if possible, the special evil design the goblins had now in their heads. Although he knew all the gangs and all the natural galleries with which they communicated in the mined part of the mountain, he had not the least idea where the palace of the king of the gnomes was; otherwise he would have set out at once on the enterprise of discovering what the said design was. He judged, and rightly, that it must lie in a farther part of the mountain, between which and the mine there was as yet no communication. There must be one nearly completed, however; for it could be but a thin partition which now separated them.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Curdie wished he could break through in time to trail the retreating goblins. A few well-placed strikes, right where he currently leaned his ear, would likely suffice. However, any attempt to use his pickaxe there would alert the goblins to his presence, prompting them to leave and potentially depriving him of their unwitting guidance. Instead, he cautiously explored the wall by hand, discovering that some stones were loose enough to be removed quietly.\n
output: If only he could get through in time to follow the goblins as they retreated! A few blows would doubtless be sufficient--just where his ear now lay; but if he attempted to strike there with his pickaxe, he would only hasten the departure of the family, put them on their guard, and perhaps lose their involuntary guidance. He therefore began to feel the wall with his hands, and soon found that some of the stones were loose enough to be drawn out with little noise.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Curdie carefully grasped a sizable stone with both hands, extracting it quietly and lowering it gently. 'Did you hear something?' inquired the goblin father. Concerned about being detected, Curdie extinguished his light to avoid giving away his position. 'It might be that lone miner who lagged behind,' suggested the mother. 'No, he left quite a while ago. I haven't heard a single strike for an hour. Besides, the sound wasn't like that,' remarked the father. 'Then perhaps it was a stone rolling down the stream within,' the mother speculated. 'Possibly. It will find more space soon enough,' replied the father.\n
output: Laying hold of a large one with both his hands, he drew it gently out, and let it down softly. 'What was that noise?' said the goblin father. Curdie blew out his light, lest it should shine through. 'It must be that one miner that stayed behind the rest,' said the mother. 'No; he's been gone a good while. I haven't heard a blow for an hour. Besides, it wasn't like that.' 'Then I suppose it must have been a stone carried down the brook inside.' 'Perhaps. It will have more room by and by.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Remaining perfectly motionless, Curdie listened intently. As the goblins busied themselves preparing to depart, interspersed with occasional instructions, his curiosity piqued. Wondering if removing the stone had created an entry into the goblins' abode, he cautiously extended his hand to explore. His hand advanced quite a distance until it encountered something soft. Before he could fully assess it, the object was swiftly withdrawn—it was one of the toeless goblin feet. Its owner emitted a startled cry.\n
output: Curdie kept quite still. After a little while, hearing nothing but the sounds of their preparations for departure, mingled with an occasional word of direction, and anxious to know whether the removal of the stone had made an opening into the goblins' house, he put in his hand to feel. It went in a good way, and then came in contact with something soft. He had but a moment to feel it over, it was so quickly withdrawn: it was one of the toeless goblin feet. The owner of it gave a cry of fright.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'What's troubling you, Helfer?' inquired his mother. 'A creature emerged from the wall and touched my foot,' he exclaimed. 'Nonsense! There are no untamed creatures here,' his father asserted. 'But it did, father. I swear I felt it.' 'Rubbish, I insist. Are you intent on besmirching our homeland and likening it to the land above? That place teems with all manner of wild beasts.' 'But I truly felt it, father.' 'I command you to cease. Such words betray a lack of patriotism.'\n
output: 'What's the matter, Helfer?' asked his mother. 'A beast came out of the wall and licked my foot.' 'Nonsense! There are no wild beasts in our country,' said his father. 'But it was, father. I felt it.' 'Nonsense, I say. Will you malign your native realms and reduce them to a level with the country upstairs? That is swarming with wild beasts of every description.' 'But I did feel it, father.' 'I tell you to hold your tongue. You are no patriot.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Curdie stifled his amusement and remained as quiet as possible, resembling a mouse—though not completely motionless, as he continuously worked his fingers around the edges of the hole. Gradually, he expanded it, taking advantage of the fractured rock caused by the previous blasting.\n
output: Curdie suppressed his laughter and lay still as a mouse--but no stiller, for every moment he kept nibbling away with his fingers at the edges of the hole. He was slowly making it bigger, for here the rock had been very much shattered with the blasting.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: The family appeared to be quite large, judging by the cacophony of voices that occasionally emanated through the opening. However, their simultaneous chatter, resembling the bristly sound of bottle brushes scraping against throats, made it difficult to discern specific conversations. After a while, Curdie caught snippets of the father goblin's words once again.\n
output: There seemed to be a good many in the family, to judge from the mass of confused talk which now and then came through the hole; but when all were speaking together, and just as if they had bottle-brushes--each at least one--in their throats, it was not easy to make out much that was said. At length he heard once more what the father goblin was saying.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'All right,' he instructed, 'load your packs onto your backs. Helfer, I'll assist you with the chest.' 'I wish it was mine, father.' 'Your time will come soon enough! Let's hurry. I must attend the gathering at the palace tonight. Once that's done, we can return and retrieve the remaining items before our adversaries return in the morning. Now, light your torches and follow me. What a privilege it is to create our own illumination instead of relying on a celestial object—a rather inconvenient invention, no doubt designed to blind us when we step out beneath its ominous glow! Quite glaring and crude, I must say, though undoubtedly beneficial for those unfortunate souls lacking the ingenuity to produce their own light.'\n
output: 'Now, then,' he said, 'get your bundles on your backs. Here, Helfer, I'll help you up with your chest.' 'I wish it was my chest, father.' 'Your turn will come in good time enough! Make haste. I must go to the meeting at the palace tonight. When that's over, we can come back and clear out the last of the things before our enemies return in the morning. Now light your torches, and come along. What a distinction it is, to provide our own light, instead of being dependent on a thing hung up in the air--a most disagreeable contrivance--intended no doubt to blind us when we venture out under its baleful influence! Quite glaring and vulgar, I call it, though no doubt useful to poor creatures who haven't the wit to make light for themselves.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Curdie fought the urge to call out and inquire if they used the fire to ignite their torches. However, he realized that they would likely claim they did, considering they struck two stones together and produced fire.\n
output: Curdie could hardly keep himself from calling through to know whether they made the fire to light their torches by. But a moment's reflection showed him that they would have said they did, inasmuch as they struck two stones together, and the fire came.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: The sound of numerous soft footsteps faded away quickly. seizing the opportunity, Curdie attacked the hole with determination, tearing and pulling until the sides yielded, creating a passage large enough for him to crawl through. He opted not to reignite his lamp to avoid detection but found enough illumination from the torches of the departing group. They were moving in a direct line up a lengthy avenue from the entrance of their cavern, providing enough light for Curdie to survey the abandoned dwelling of the goblins.\n
output: A sound of many soft feet followed, but soon ceased. Then Curdie flew at the hole like a tiger, and tore and pulled. The sides gave way, and it was soon large enough for him to crawl through. He would not betray himself by rekindling his lamp, but the torches of the retreating company, which he found departing in a straight line up a long avenue from the door of their cave, threw back light enough to afford him a glance round the deserted home of the goblins.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Much to his surprise, he found nothing that set it apart from any other natural cave in the rock, similar to many he had encountered during their mining endeavors. Despite the goblins' discussion of returning for their remaining belongings, there was nothing to indicate that a family had sought refuge there for even a brief period.\n
output: To his surprise, he could discover nothing to distinguish it from an ordinary natural cave in the rock, upon many of which he had come with the rest of the miners in the progress of their excavations. The goblins had talked of coming back for the rest of their household gear: he saw nothing that would have made him suspect a family had taken shelter there for a single night.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: The floor was uneven and rocky, the walls jagged with protrusions, and the ceiling varied in height, posing a potential hazard to his head in some areas. Additionally, a narrow stream trickled down one side of the rock, creating a dampness that spread across the wall.\n
output: The floor was rough and stony; the walls full of projecting corners; the roof in one place twenty feet high, in another endangering his forehead; while on one side a stream, no thicker than a needle, it is true, but still sufficient to spread a wide dampness over the wall, flowed down the face of the rock.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Ahead of him, the group labored under heavy loads. Occasionally, he caught sight of Helfer struggling with a bulky chest on his stooped back, while the other brother seemed almost engulfed in what resembled a large feather mattress. Curdie wondered where they acquired the feathers, but the troop soon vanished around a bend, prompting him to hurry after them to avoid losing sight of them completely.\n
output: But the troop in front of him was toiling under heavy burdens. He could distinguish Helfer now and then, in the flickering light and shade, with his heavy chest on his bending shoulders; while the second brother was almost buried in what looked like a great feather bed. 'Where do they get the feathers?' thought Curdie; but in a moment the troop disappeared at a turn of the way, and it was now both safe and necessary for Curdie to follow them, lest they should be round the next turning before he saw them again, for so he might lose them altogether.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: He dashed after them with the agility of a greyhound. Peering around the corner, he spotted them farther down another lengthy corridor. None of the passages he traversed that night exhibited any traces of human or goblin activity. Ancient stalactites adorned the ceilings, evidence of a time long before mining operations began, while the floors were strewn with boulders and sizable stones, indicating the presence of water at some point.\n
output: He darted after them like a greyhound. When he reached the corner and looked cautiously round, he saw them again at some distance down another long passage. None of the galleries he saw that night bore signs of the work of man--or of goblin either. Stalactites, far older than the mines, hung from their roofs; and their floors were rough with boulders and large round stones, showing that there water must have once run.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: He lingered once more at the corner until they vanished around the following bend, trailing them through a series of interconnected passages. These corridors gradually increased in height and became adorned with an abundance of glistening stalactites hanging from the ceiling.\n
output: He waited again at this corner till they had disappeared round the next, and so followed them a long way through one passage after another. The passages grew more and more lofty, and were more and more covered in the roof with shining stalactites.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: The procession he trailed behind was peculiar, to say the least. However, the most peculiar aspect was the presence of household animals mingling among the goblins' feet. While there were no wild creatures down there, as far as they knew, there was an impressive array of domesticated ones. Further details about these creatures will be revealed later in the story.\n
output: It was a strange enough procession which he followed. But the strangest part of it was the household animals which crowded amongst the feet of the goblins. It was true they had no wild animals down there--at least they did not know of any; but they had a wonderful number of tame ones. I must, however, reserve any contributions towards the natural history of these for a later position in my story.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: After navigating the passages for a while, he nearly stumbled upon the goblin family as they paused in a cavern larger than the last. They were still catching their breath, preventing any immediate communication. Sensing the danger of being discovered, he quickly withdrew and observed from a safe distance, anticipating the father's departure for the palace.\n
output: At length, turning a corner too abruptly, he had almost rushed into the middle of the goblin family; for there they had already set down all their burdens on the floor of a cave considerably larger than that which they had left. They were as yet too breathless to speak, else he would have had warning of their arrest. He started back, however, before anyone saw him, and retreating a good way, stood watching till the father should come out to go to the palace.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Shortly after, both the goblin father and his son Helfer emerged and continued on their path, prompting Curdie to resume his cautious pursuit. For a while, the only sound he perceived was akin to the flow of a river within the caverns. Eventually, he caught a distant clamor, resembling shouts, which soon faded away.\n
output: Before very long, both he and his son Helfer appeared and kept on in the same direction as before, while Curdie followed them again with renewed precaution. For a long time he heard no sound except something like the rush of a river inside the rock; but at length what seemed the far-off noise of a great shouting reached his ears, which, however, presently ceased.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Continuing his journey deeper into the tunnels, Curdie perceived the distinct sound of a solitary voice. Its clarity increased with each step he took, until he could nearly discern the words being spoken. Suddenly, as he followed the goblins around another bend, he recoiled in astonishment.\n
output: After advancing a good way farther, he thought he heard a single voice. It sounded clearer and clearer as he went on, until at last he could almost distinguish the words. In a moment or two, keeping after the goblins round another corner, he once more started back--this time in amazement.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Standing at the threshold of a grand cavern, its oval form suggested it might have once served as a vast natural reservoir, now repurposed as the majestic palace hall of the goblins. Though towering in height, the roof gleamed with luminous materials, and the numerous torches held by the bustling goblins below illuminated the space, allowing Curdie a clear view to the ceiling.\n
output: He was at the entrance of a magnificent cavern, of an oval shape, once probably a huge natural reservoir of water, now the great palace hall of the goblins. It rose to a tremendous height, but the roof was composed of such shining materials, and the multitude of torches carried by the goblins who crowded the floor lighted up the place so brilliantly, that Curdie could see to the top quite well.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Only after several minutes did Curdie begin to grasp the immense scale of the cavern. The jagged protrusions on the walls, cast into relief by the torchlight, created an illusion of statues on ornate platforms, seemingly extending from floor to ceiling in haphazard tiers. Portions of the walls were composed of resplendent materials, some adorned with vibrant hues, creating a striking juxtaposition against the shadowy depths.\n
output: But he had no idea how immense the place was until his eyes had got accustomed to it, which was not for a good many minutes. The rough projections on the walls, and the shadows thrown upwards from them by the torches, made the sides of the chamber look as if they were crowded with statues upon brackets and pedestals, reaching in irregular tiers from floor to roof. The walls themselves were, in many parts, of gloriously shining substances, some of them gorgeously coloured besides, which powerfully contrasted with the shadows.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Curdie pondered whether his rhymes would have any effect against the horde of goblins that swarmed the hall. Tempted to start his chant, he resisted, realizing the importance of remaining silent to uncover their intentions. Instead, he stayed hidden, keenly listening with his acute hearing.\n
output: Curdie could not help wondering whether his rhymes would be of any use against such a multitude of goblins as filled the floor of the hall, and indeed felt considerably tempted to begin his shout of 'One, two, three!', but as there was no reason for routing them and much for endeavouring to discover their designs, he kept himself perfectly quiet, and peering round the edge of the doorway, listened with both his sharp ears.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: On the far end of the hall, above the throng, was a terrace-like ledge formed by the cave's upper recess. The king and his court occupied this space: the king seated on a throne carved from a massive block of green copper ore, surrounded by his court on lower seats. Having just delivered a speech, the king's applause echoed through the hall. Now, one of his court addressed the assembly, outlining the king's plans for the deliverance of their people. Despite their historical ownership of the lands now inhabited by others and their noble reasons for departure, they faced mockery and disdain. Yet, with the king's inventive genius, revenge against their adversaries was imminent.\n
output: At the other end of the hall, high above the heads of the multitude, was a terrace-like ledge of considerable height, caused by the receding of the upper part of the cavern-wall. Upon this sat the king and his court: the king on a throne hollowed out of a huge block of green copper ore, and his court upon lower seats around it. The king had been making them a speech, and the applause which followed it was what Curdie had heard. One of the court was now addressing the multitude. What he heard him say was to the following effect: 'Hence it appears that two plans have been for some time together working in the strong head of His Majesty for the deliverance of his people. Regardless of the fact that we were the first possessors of the regions they now inhabit; regardless equally of the fact that we abandoned that region from the loftiest motives; regardless also of the self-evident fact that we excel them so far in mental ability as they excel us in stature, they look upon us as a degraded race and make a mockery of all our finer feelings. But, the time has almost arrived when--thanks to His Majesty's inventive genius--it will be in our power to take a thorough revenge upon them once for all, in respect of their unfriendly behaviour.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'Your Majesty's pardon,' exclaimed a voice near the entrance, recognizable to Curdie as that of the goblin he had been trailing. 'Who dares interrupt the Chancellor?' bellowed another voice from the vicinity of the throne. 'Glump,' chorused several voices. 'He is our loyal subject,' proclaimed the king himself, his voice deliberate and dignified. 'Let him step forward and address us.' A path cleared through the crowd, allowing Glump to ascend the platform and bow before the king before speaking. 'Sire, I would have remained silent, but I am aware of the imminent moment referenced by the Chancellor. It is likely that by tomorrow, the enemy will have breached my dwelling—the partition between us now barely a foot thick.' 'Not even that,' Curdie mused to himself. 'Tonight, I had to relocate my belongings, hence the urgency to proceed with the plan for which Your Majesty has made grand preparations. Additionally, I recently noticed a disturbance in my dining room, coupled with changes in the river's flow near the intruders' entry point, indicating a probable chasm nearby. This discovery should significantly bolster Your Majesty's formidable forces.' With his speech concluded, the king graciously acknowledged Glump's contribution with a nod, prompting Glump to bow once more before blending back into the crowd.\n
output: 'May it please Your Majesty--' cried a voice close by the door, which Curdie recognized as that of the goblin he had followed. 'Who is he that interrupts the Chancellor?' cried another from near the throne. 'Glump,' answered several voices. 'He is our trusty subject,' said the king himself, in a slow and stately voice: 'let him come forward and speak.' A lane was parted through the crowd, and Glump, having ascended the platform and bowed to the king, spoke as follows: 'Sire, I would have held my peace, had I not known that I only knew how near was the moment, to which the Chancellor had just referred. In all probability, before another day is past, the enemy will have broken through into my house--the partition between being even now not more than a foot in thickness.' 'Not quite so much,' thought Curdie to himself. 'This very evening I have had to remove my household effects; therefore the sooner we are ready to carry out the plan, for the execution of which His Majesty has been making such magnificent preparations, the better. I may just add, that within the last few days I have perceived a small outbreak in my dining-room, which, combined with observations upon the course of the river escaping where the evil men enter, has convinced me that close to the spot must be a deep gulf in its channel. This discovery will, I trust, add considerably to the otherwise immense forces at His Majesty's disposal.' He ceased, and the king graciously acknowledged his speech with a bend of his head; whereupon Glump, after a bow to His Majesty, slid down amongst the rest of the undistinguished multitude.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Next, the Chancellor stood up and continued, 'The valuable information provided by Glump could have held significance, were it not for the other plan already mentioned, which naturally takes precedence. His Majesty, reluctant to resort to extreme measures and mindful of the potential repercussions, has devised a more comprehensive approach, details of which I need not elaborate on. Should His Majesty succeed—as who would dare to doubt?—then a lasting peace, greatly benefiting the goblin kingdom, will be ensured for at least a generation, strengthened by the assurance that His Royal Highness the prince will guarantee the good conduct of their allies. However, should His Majesty falter—which none would even dare to contemplate—then it will be time to implement the plan mentioned by Glump, for which our preparations are nearly complete. The failure of the former option will necessitate the latter.'\n
output: Then the Chancellor rose and resumed. 'The information which the worthy Glump has given us,' he said, 'might have been of considerable import at the present moment, but for that other design already referred to, which naturally takes precedence. His Majesty, unwilling to proceed to extremities, and well aware that such measures sooner or later result in violent reactions, has excogitated a more fundamental and comprehensive measure, of which I need say no more. Should His Majesty be successful--as who dares to doubt?--then a peace, all to the advantage of the goblin kingdom, will be established for a generation at least, rendered absolutely secure by the pledge which His Royal Highness the prince will have and hold for the good behaviour of her relatives. Should His Majesty fail--which who shall dare even to imagine in his most secret thoughts?--then will be the time for carrying out with rigour the design to which Glump referred, and for which our preparations are even now all but completed. The failure of the former will render the latter imperative.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Observing that the meeting was coming to an end and realizing that he had little opportunity to uncover either plan further, Curdie deemed it wise to depart before the goblins dispersed, slipping away quietly. While there was minimal risk of encountering goblins, as all the men were still in the palace, there was a significant danger of getting lost without a light, relying solely on his memory and sense of touch. Once he had moved beyond the glow emanating from Glump's new dwelling, he was without visual guidance. He was eager to return through the hole before the goblins came back for their belongings. Not out of fear, but because it was crucial to fully understand their schemes without arousing any suspicion of being watched by a miner.\n
output: Curdie, perceiving that the assembly was drawing to a close and that there was little chance of either plan being more fully discovered, now thought it prudent to make his escape before the goblins began to disperse, and slipped quietly away. There was not much danger of meeting any goblins, for all the men at least were left behind him in the palace; but there was considerable danger of his taking a wrong turning, for he had now no light, and had therefore to depend upon his memory and his hands. After he had left behind him the glow that issued from the door of Glump's new abode, he was utterly without guide, so far as his eyes were concerned. He was most anxious to get back through the hole before the goblins should return to fetch the remains of their furniture. It was not that he was in the least afraid of them, but, as it was of the utmost importance that he should thoroughly discover what the plans they were cherishing were, he must not occasion the slightest suspicion that they were watched by a miner.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: He pressed forward, tracing the rocky walls with his hands. Despite his courage, anxiety gnawed at him, knowing that losing his way would be a daunting predicament. These depths offered no prospect of morning light, and courtesy from goblins, especially towards him, known as a notorious adversary, was improbable. He regretted not bringing his lamp and tinderbox, a thought that hadn't occurred to him in his eagerness to pursue the goblins. His regret intensified when he encountered an obstruction, unable to proceed further. Turning back seemed futile, as he had no clue where he had veered off course. Yet, he mechanically explored the enclosing walls, discovering a tiny stream trickling down the rock. 'How foolish of me!' he muttered. 'I've reached the end of my journey without realizing it! And here come the goblins to reclaim their belongings!' he exclaimed as he glimpsed the red glow of their torches at the distant cave entrance. Hastily, he threw himself to the ground and wriggled backward through the hole. The lower floor on the other side eased his retreat. Though straining, he managed to replace the largest stone he had removed. Sitting atop the pile of ore, he contemplated his next move.\n
output: He hurried on, feeling his way along the walls of rock. Had he not been very courageous, he must have been very anxious, for he could not but know that if he lost his way it would be the most difficult thing in the world to find it again. Morning would bring no light into these regions; and towards him least of all, who was known as a special rhymester and persecutor, could goblins be expected to exercise courtesy. Well might he wish that he had brought his lamp and tinder-box with him, of which he had not thought when he crept so eagerly after the goblins! He wished it all the more when, after a while, he found his way blocked up, and could get no farther. It was of no use to turn back, for he had not the least idea where he had begun to go wrong. Mechanically, however, he kept feeling about the walls that hemmed him in. His hand came upon a place where a tiny stream of water was running down the face of the rock. 'What a stupid I am!' he said to himself. 'I am actually at the end of my journey! And there are the goblins coming back to fetch their things!' he added, as the red glimmer of their torches appeared at the end of the long avenue that led up to the cave. In a moment he had thrown himself on the floor, and wriggled backwards through the hole. The floor on the other side was several feet lower, which made it easier to get back. It was all he could do to lift the largest stone he had taken out of the hole, but he did manage to shove it in again. He sat down on the ore-heap and thought.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Curdie had a strong suspicion that the goblins' alternative scheme involved flooding the mine by creating openings to release water from the mountain's natural reservoirs, as well as diverting existing watercourses. While the miners' section had been isolated from the goblins' domain, they hadn't been vulnerable to such attacks. However, with a passage now breached and the goblins' domain situated higher in the mountain, Curdie realized the mine could be submerged in a matter of hours. Water was always the miners' primary hazard, although they occasionally encountered choke-damp, but never the explosive firedamp prevalent in coal mines. Therefore, they were vigilant at the slightest hint of water. Reflecting on this while the goblins were preoccupied, Curdie concluded that it was best to seal off the entire passage, filling it with stone, clay, or mud to prevent any water ingress. Although there was no immediate peril, as the goblins' plan hinged on the failure of another undisclosed design, Curdie was eager to maintain communication to uncover the primary plan. Yet, if the goblins resumed their efforts to flood the mine, he would swiftly mobilize the miners to fortify the existing outlet, ensuring it could withstand any water pressure by reinforcing it with the mountain's natural rock.\n
output: He was pretty sure that the latter plan of the goblins was to inundate the mine by breaking outlets for the water accumulated in the natural reservoirs of the mountain, as well as running through portions of it. While the part hollowed by the miners remained shut off from that inhabited by the goblins, they had had no opportunity of injuring them thus; but now that a passage was broken through, and the goblins' part proved the higher in the mountain, it was clear to Curdie that the mine could be destroyed in an hour. Water was always the chief danger to which the miners were exposed. They met with a little choke-damp sometimes, but never with the explosive firedamp so common in coal-mines. Hence they were careful as soon as they saw any appearance of water. As the result of his reflections while the goblins were busy in their old home, it seemed to Curdie that it would be best to build up the whole of this gang, filling it with stone, and clay or lie, so that there should be no smallest channel for the water to get into. There was not, however, any immediate danger, for the execution of the goblins' plan was contingent upon the failure of that unknown design which was to take precedence of it; and he was most anxious to keep the door of communication open, that he might if possible discover what the former plan was. At the same time they could not resume their intermitted labours for the inundation without his finding it out; when by putting all hands to the work, the one existing outlet might in a single night be rendered impenetrable to any weight of water; for by filling the gang entirely up, their embankment would be buttressed by the sides of the mountain itself.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Once he confirmed that the goblins had departed again, Curdie lit his lamp and began filling the hole he had excavated with removable stones. Recognizing the likelihood of many sleepless nights ahead, he decided it was wise to return home and get some rest. The cool night air outside the mountain provided a welcome relief after his underground ordeal. He ascended the hill without encountering any goblins along the way, and roused his father by tapping on the window until he awoke. After recounting the entire tale, as anticipated, his father agreed to cease mining in that vein but to maintain a pretense of activity occasionally to avoid arousing suspicion among the goblins. Father and son then retired to bed and slept soundly until morning.\n
output: As soon as he found that the goblins had again retired, he lighted his lamp, and proceeded to fill the hole he had made with such stones as he could withdraw when he pleased. He then thought it better, as he might have occasion to be up a good many nights after this, to go home and have some sleep. How pleasant the night air felt upon the outside of the mountain after what he had gone through in the inside of it! He hurried up the hill without meeting a single goblin on the way, and called and tapped at the window until he woke his father, who soon rose and let him in. He told him the whole story; and, just as he had expected, his father thought it best to work that lode no farther, but at the same time to pretend occasionally to be at work there still in order that the goblins might have no suspicions. Both father and son then went to bed and slept soundly until the morning.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: The weather remained delightful for weeks, allowing the little princess to enjoy outdoor excursions every day. Such an extended period of fine weather was unprecedented on the mountain. However, the only drawback was the excessive caution of her nurse, who insisted on returning home before sunset. Even the slightest shadow caused her to panic, resulting in early departures on many evenings, often an hour before the sun had set completely. Despite her nurse's peculiar behavior, Irene's memory of the goblins was beginning to fade. However, she never forgot about Curdie, not only because of their encounter but also because a princess always remembers her debts until they are repaid.\n
output: The weather continued fine for weeks, and the little princess went out every day. So long a period of fine weather had indeed never been known upon that mountain. The only uncomfortable thing was that her nurse was so nervous and particular about being in before the sun was down that often she would take to her heels when nothing worse than a fleecy cloud crossing the sun threw a shadow on the hillside; and many an evening they were home a full hour before the sunlight had left the weather-cock on the stables. If it had not been for such odd behaviour Irene would by this time have almost forgotten the goblins. She never forgot Curdie, but him she remembered for his own sake, and indeed would have remembered him if only because a princess never forgets her debts until they are paid.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: On a glorious sunny day, just after noon, Irene was playing on the lawn in the garden when she heard the distant sound of a bugle. Her heart leaped with joy, recognizing the particular blast that announced her father's arrival. The garden, situated on the slope of a hill, offered a clear view of the surrounding countryside. She shielded her eyes with her hand and scanned the horizon, eagerly anticipating the sight of shining armor. Soon, a small procession emerged, glinting in the sunlight as they rounded the hill. Spears and helmets flashed, banners waved, horses pranced, and the bugle sounded once more, echoing her father's message across the distance: 'Irene, I'm coming.'\n
output: One splendid sunshiny day, about an hour after noon, Irene, who was playing on a lawn in the garden, heard the distant blast of a bugle. She jumped up with a cry of joy, for she knew by that particular blast that her father was on his way to see her. This part of the garden lay on the slope of the hill and allowed a full view of the country below. So she shaded her eyes with her hand and looked far away to catch the first glimpse of shining armour. In a few moments a little troop came glittering round the shoulder of a hill. Spears and helmets were sparkling and gleaming, banners were flying, horses prancing, and again came the bugle-blast which was to her like the voice of her father calling across the distance: 'Irene, I'm coming.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: They continued to draw nearer until Irene could clearly make out the figure of the king. He rode atop a majestic white steed, towering over the men around him. Adorning his helmet was a narrow band of gold studded with precious jewels, their brilliance catching the sunlight. It had been quite some time since his last visit, and Irene's heart fluttered with excitement as the radiant procession approached. She cherished her king-father dearly, and there was nowhere she felt happier than in his embrace. As they reached a certain point beyond her view from the garden, she rushed to the gate, eagerly awaiting their arrival, until finally they emerged, their armor clanging and hooves stamping, accompanied by one final triumphant bugle call signaling, 'Irene, I have arrived.'\n
output: On and on they came until she could clearly distinguish the king. He rode a white horse and was taller than any of the men with him. He wore a narrow circle of gold set with jewels around his helmet, and as he came still nearer Irene could discern the flashing of the stones in the sun. It was a long time since he had been to see her, and her little heart beat faster and faster as the shining troop approached, for she loved her king-papa very dearly and was nowhere so happy as in his arms. When they reached a certain point, after which she could see them no more from the garden, she ran to the gate, and there stood till up they came, clanging and stamping, with one more bright bugle-blast which said: 'Irene, I am come.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: As the horsemen arrived, Irene stood alone at the forefront, eagerly awaiting their approach. Upon their halt, she rushed to the side of the magnificent white horse, reaching out her arms. The king, noticing her, stopped and took her hands, swiftly lifting her onto the saddle and enveloping her in his powerful embrace. It's difficult to capture the king's essence in mere words, but imagine gentle blue eyes juxtaposed with a nose reminiscent of an eagle's. His long, dark beard, streaked with silver, cascaded down to his waist, mingling with Irene's golden locks as she nestled against him. After a brief moment, he whispered to his steed, which, sensing the precious cargo it bore, moved with utmost grace towards the gate and then to the house's entrance. There, the king gently placed Irene on the ground, leading her by the hand into the grand hall, a space rarely frequented except during his visits to his beloved princess. Taking a seat alongside two of his counselors, the king indulged in refreshments, while Irene, seated at his right hand, sipped from a delicately carved wooden bowl.\n
output: By this time the people of the house were all gathered at the gate, but Irene stood alone in front of them. When the horsemen pulled up she ran to the side of the white horse and held up her arms. The king stopped and took her hands. In an instant she was on the saddle and clasped in his great strong arms. I wish I could describe the king so that you could see him in your mind. He had gentle, blue eyes, but a nose that made him look like an eagle. A long dark beard, streaked with silvery lines, flowed from his mouth almost to his waist, and as Irene sat on the saddle and hid her glad face upon his bosom it mingled with the golden hair which her mother had given her, and the two together were like a cloud with streaks of the sun woven through it. After he had held her to his heart for a minute he spoke to his white horse, and the great beautiful creature, which had been prancing so proudly a little while before, walked as gently as a lady--for he knew he had a little lady on his back--through the gate and up to the door of the house. Then the king set her on the ground and, dismounting, took her hand and walked with her into the great hall, which was hardly ever entered except when he came to see his little princess. There he sat down, with two of his counsellors who had accompanied him, to have some refreshment, and Irene sat on his right hand and drank her milk out of a wooden bowl curiously carved.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: After finishing his meal, the king turned to the princess, gently stroking her hair, and asked, 'What shall we do next, my child?' This question was a customary post-meal ritual between them, and Irene had been eagerly awaiting it, as she hoped to resolve a lingering question. 'I would like to visit my great-grandmother,' she replied earnestly. The king's expression turned solemn as he inquired, 'What do you mean, my dear?' 'I mean the Queen Irene who resides in the tower—the elderly lady with the long silver hair,' she explained. The king regarded his daughter with a puzzled expression. 'She keeps her crown in her bedroom,' Irene continued, 'but I haven't been inside yet. You know she's there, don't you?' 'No,' replied the king quietly. 'Then it must all be a dream,' Irene concluded. 'I had my doubts, but now I'm certain. Besides, I couldn't find her the last time I looked.' Just then, a snow-white pigeon flew in through an open window and perched on Irene's head. She laughed, slightly startled, and gently urged the bird not to peck her. The king reached out to catch the pigeon, but it swiftly flew away, disappearing into the sunlight. He then placed his hand on Irene's head, studying her face with a mixture of affection and contemplation, before offering a faint smile and a soft sigh.\n
output: After the king had eaten and drunk he turned to the princess and said, stroking her hair: 'Now, my child, what shall we do next?' This was the question he almost always put to her first after their meal together; and Irene had been waiting for it with some impatience, for now, she thought, she should be able to settle a question which constantly perplexed her. 'I should like you to take me to see my great old grandmother.' The king looked grave and said: 'What does my little daughter mean?' 'I mean the Queen Irene that lives up in the tower--the very old lady, you know, with the long hair of silver.' The king only gazed at his little princess with a look which she could not understand. 'She's got her crown in her bedroom,' she went on; 'but I've not been in there yet. You know she's there, don't you?' 'No,' said the king, very quietly. 'Then it must all be a dream,' said Irene. 'I half thought it was; but I couldn't be sure. Now I am sure of it. Besides, I couldn't find her the next time I went up.' At that moment a snow-white pigeon flew in at an open window and settled upon Irene's head. She broke into a merry laugh, cowered a little, and put up her hands to her head, saying: 'Dear dovey, don't peck me. You'll pull out my hair with your long claws if you don't mind.' The king stretched out his hand to take the pigeon, but it spread its wings and flew again through the open window, when its whiteness made one flash in the sun and vanished. The king laid his hand on his princess's head, held it back a little, gazed in her face, smiled half a smile, and sighed half a sigh.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'Come, my dear; let's take a stroll in the garden together,' he suggested warmly. 'But won't you come and visit my enormous, magnificent grandmother with me, king-papa?' inquired the princess. 'Not today,' replied the king gently. 'You see, she hasn't extended an invitation to me, and distinguished elderly ladies like her prefer visitors to seek permission before arriving.' The garden was truly enchanting. Situated on the mountainside, it featured rocky outcrops scattered throughout, lending a rugged charm to the landscape. Clusters of heather and other hardy mountain flora adorned these rocks, while nearby, more delicate roses, lilies, and other garden blooms flourished. This harmonious blend of untamed mountain terrain and cultivated garden was both charming and unconventional, defying any attempts to impose a formal or rigid structure upon its natural beauty.\n
output: 'Come, my child; we'll have a walk in the garden together,' he said. 'You won't come up and see my huge, great, beautiful grandmother, then, king-papa?' said the princess. 'Not this time,' said the king very gently. 'She has not invited me, you know, and great old ladies like her do not choose to be visited without leave asked and given.' The garden was a very lovely place. Being upon a mountainside there were parts in it where the rocks came through in great masses, and all immediately about them remained quite wild. Tufts of heather grew upon them, and other hardy mountain plants and flowers, while near them would be lovely roses and lilies and all pleasant garden flowers. This mingling of the wild mountain with the civilized garden was very quaint, and it was impossible for any number of gardeners to make such a garden look formal and stiff.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Nestled against one of these rocky formations stood a quaint garden bench, sheltered from the afternoon sun by the natural overhang of the rock itself. A small winding path led up to the summit of the rock, where another bench awaited, but they chose to sit at the base of the rock to avoid the intense heat of the sun. There, they engaged in a heartfelt conversation on various topics. Eventually, the king remarked, 'You were out quite late one evening, Irene.' 'Yes, Papa. It was my fault, and Lootie felt very remorseful.' 'I'll have a word with Lootie about it,' the king decided. 'Please, Papa, be gentle with her,' Irene pleaded. 'She's been so fearful of being tardy since then! She truly hasn't been mischievous; it was just a one-time mistake.' 'Once may be one time too many,' the king muttered to himself, gently caressing his child's head.\n
output: Against one of these rocks was a garden seat, shadowed from the afternoon sun by the overhanging of the rock itself. There was a little winding path up to the top of the rock, and on top another seat; but they sat on the seat at its foot because the sun was hot; and there they talked together of many things. At length the king said: 'You were out late one evening, Irene.' 'Yes, papa. It was my fault; and Lootie was very sorry.' 'I must talk to Lootie about it,' said the king. 'Don't speak loud to her, please, papa,' said Irene. 'She's been so afraid of being late ever since! Indeed she has not been naughty. It was only a mistake for once.' 'Once might be too often,' murmured the king to himself, as he stroked his child's head.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: I can't say exactly how he came to find out. I'm certain Curdie hadn't informed him. Somehow, word must have reached someone in the palace. He sat pondering for a while. The only sound was the gentle babbling of a nearby stream that flowed cheerfully out of a crevice in the rock where they were seated, then meandered down the hillside through the garden. Eventually, he stood up and, leaving Irene behind, entered the house and summoned Lootie. Their conversation left her in tears. When he departed in the evening on his majestic white steed, he left six of his attendants behind, instructing three of them to keep watch outside the house every night, patrolling around it from dusk till dawn. It was evident he harbored some concerns regarding the safety of the princess.\n
output: I can't tell you how he had come to know. I am sure Curdie had not told him. Someone about the palace must have seen them, after all. He sat for a good while thinking. There was no sound to be heard except that of a little stream which ran merrily out of an opening in the rock by where they sat, and sped away down the hill through the garden. Then he rose and, leaving Irene where she was, went into the house and sent for Lootie, with whom he had a talk that made her cry. When in the evening he rode away upon his great white horse, he left six of his attendants behind him, with orders that three of them should watch outside the house every night, walking round and round it from sunset to sunrise. It was clear he was not quite comfortable about the princess.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Not much of note occurred for a while. Autumn passed by swiftly. The garden lost its blooms, and the wind howled through the rocks. Rain poured down, soaking the few remaining yellow and red leaves clinging to the bare branches. There were days of glorious mornings followed by rainy afternoons, and sometimes a week straight of continuous rain, only to be followed by a clear, starry night. Unfortunately, the princess missed much of the starlit skies as she retired early. Winter approached, and she found herself growing weary. On stormy days when venturing outside was impossible and her toys ceased to entertain, Lootie would lead her around the house. Sometimes they visited the housekeeper, a kind soul who treated her like family. Other times, they ventured into the servants' hall or the kitchen, where she ruled as queen and risked being spoiled. Occasionally, she visited the room where the king's guards gathered, marveling at their weapons and attempts to entertain her. Yet, despite these distractions, she often felt a sense of dreariness and found herself wishing her great grandmother hadn't been merely a dream.\n
output: Nothing more happened worth telling for some time. The autumn came and went by. There were no more flowers in the garden. The wind blew strong, and howled among the rocks. The rain fell, and drenched the few yellow and red leaves that could not get off the bare branches. Again and again there would be a glorious morning followed by a pouring afternoon, and sometimes, for a week together, there would be rain, nothing but rain, all day, and then the most lovely cloudless night, with the sky all out in full-blown stars--not one missing. But the princess could not see much of them, for she went to bed early. The winter drew on, and she found things growing dreary. When it was too stormy to go out, and she had got tired of her toys, Lootie would take her about the house, sometimes to the housekeeper's room, where the housekeeper, who was a good, kind old woman, made much of her--sometimes to the servants' hall or the kitchen, where she was not princess merely, but absolute queen, and ran a great risk of being spoiled. Sometimes she would run off herself to the room where the men-at-arms whom the king had left sat, and they showed her their arms and accoutrements and did what they could to amuse her. Still at times she found it very dreary, and often and often wished that her huge great grandmother had not been a dream.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: One morning, the nurse entrusted her to the care of the housekeeper for a brief period. In an attempt to entertain her, the housekeeper emptied the contents of an old cabinet onto the table. The young princess found the assortment of peculiar ancient ornaments and various mysterious objects far more captivating than her usual toys, engrossing herself in play for over two hours. However, while handling a curious old-fashioned brooch, she accidentally pricked her thumb with its pin, emitting a small cry from the sudden pain. Initially, she thought little of it, but as the pain intensified and her thumb began to swell, it caused great concern to the housekeeper. The nurse was summoned, and a doctor was urgently called for. The princess's hand was poulticed, and she was put to bed much earlier than usual. Despite falling asleep and experiencing numerous dreams, the pain persisted, haunting her even in her dreams until it finally roused her from her slumber.\n
output: One morning the nurse left her with the housekeeper for a while. To amuse her she turned out the contents of an old cabinet upon the table. The little princess found her treasures, queer ancient ornaments, and many things the use of which she could not imagine, far more interesting than her own toys, and sat playing with them for two hours or more. But, at length, in handling a curious old-fashioned brooch, she ran the pin of it into her thumb, and gave a little scream with the sharpness of the pain, but would have thought little more of it had not the pain increased and her thumb begun to swell. This alarmed the housekeeper greatly. The nurse was fetched; the doctor was sent for; her hand was poulticed, and long before her usual time she was put to bed. The pain still continued, and although she fell asleep and dreamed a good many dreams, there was the pain always in every dream. At last it woke her UP.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: The room was bathed in the bright light of the moon streaming through the window. The poultice had slipped off her hand, and it felt unbearably hot. In a desperate attempt to soothe the burning sensation, she believed that exposing it to the moonlight would provide relief. Quietly, without disturbing the nurse who slept at the far end of the room, she slipped out of bed and made her way to the window. Peering outside, she spotted one of the men-at-arms patrolling the garden, his armor gleaming in the moon's glow. Tempted to call out to him and share her discomfort, she hesitated, mindful of the risk of waking the nurse. Instead, she decided to seek solace by approaching another window in a different room. The thought of having someone to converse with outweighed the prospect of lying in bed, grappling with the throbbing pain in her hand. With utmost care, she quietly traversed through the nursery, which had no view of the garden, aiming for the alternate window.\n
output: The moon was shining brightly into the room. The poultice had fallen off her hand and it was burning hot. She fancied if she could hold it into the moonlight that would cool it. So she got out of bed, without waking the nurse who lay at the other end of the room, and went to the window. When she looked out she saw one of the men-at-arms walking in the garden with the moonlight glancing on his armour. She was just going to tap on the window and call him, for she wanted to tell him all about it, when she bethought herself that that might wake Lootie, and she would put her into her bed again. So she resolved to go to the window of another room, and call him from there. It was so much nicer to have somebody to talk to than to lie awake in bed with the burning pain in her hand. She opened the door very gently and went through the nursery, which did not look into the garden, to go to the other window.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: Intrigued by the possibility of encountering her beloved old grandmother, she whispered to herself with anticipation as she ascended the steep staircase. Upon reaching the summit, enveloped in darkness as the moonlight failed to penetrate, she paused to listen intently. And there it was—the familiar sound of the spinning wheel whirring diligently. Remarkable that her grandmother toiled tirelessly both day and night! With a soft tap, she gently rapped on the door, eager to reunite with her.\n
output: 'What if I should really-really find my beautiful old grandmother up there!' she said to herself as she crept up the steep steps. When she reached the top she stood a moment listening in the dark, for there was no moon there. Yes! it was! it was the hum of the spinning-wheel! What a diligent grandmother to work both day and night! She tapped gently at the door.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'Step inside, Irene,' beckoned the gentle voice. With a sense of wonder, the princess pushed open the door and stepped into the room. Moonbeams flooded through the window, casting an ethereal glow, and amidst the luminous light sat the elderly woman in her somber attire adorned with delicate white lace, her silver hair blending seamlessly with the moon's radiance. 'Come closer, Irene,' she invited once more. 'Can you discern what lies upon my spinning wheel?'\n
output: 'Come in, Irene,' said the sweet voice. The princess opened the door and entered. There was the moonlight streaming in at the window, and in the middle of the moonlight sat the old lady in her black dress with the white lace, and her silvery hair mingling with the moonlight, so that you could not have told which was which. 'Come in, Irene,' she said again. 'Can you tell me what I am spinning?'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'She converses,' pondered Irene, 'as if our meeting occurred mere moments ago, or at most, yesterday. --No,' she responded, 'I am unable to discern the material on your spinning wheel. Please, I presumed you were but a figment of my imagination. Why did I struggle to find you earlier, great-great-grandmother?' 'That is a concept you may not fully grasp at your tender age. However, I can offer one explanation for my elusive nature. I deliberately eluded your discovery.' 'But why, may I inquire?' 'Because I wished to remain concealed from Lootie.' 'Yet, you instructed me to inform Lootie.' 'Indeed. However, I was aware that Lootie would doubt your words. Even if she were to witness me spinning here, she would remain skeptical.'\n
output: 'She speaks,' thought Irene, 'just as if she had seen me five minutes ago, or yesterday at the farthest. --No,' she answered; 'I don't know what you are spinning. Please, I thought you were a dream. Why couldn't I find you before, great-great-grandmother?' 'That you are hardly old enough to understand. But you would have found me sooner if you hadn't come to think I was a dream. I will give you one reason though why you couldn't find me. I didn't want you to find me.' 'Why, please?' 'Because I did not want Lootie to know I was here.' 'But you told me to tell Lootie.' 'Yes. But I knew Lootie would not believe you. If she were to see me sitting spinning here, she wouldn't believe me, either.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'Why?' 'Because she couldn't. She would rub her eyes, dismiss it as a peculiar sensation, and then forget most of it, chalking it up to a dream.' 'Just as I did,' admitted Irene, feeling a pang of guilt. 'Indeed, quite similar to you, but not entirely. You've returned; Lootie wouldn't have. She would have rejected it as nonsensical.' 'Would that be wrong of Lootie?' 'It would be wrong of you. I have no obligation to Lootie.' 'But you did care for me, washing my face and hands,' tearfully recalled Irene.\n
output: 'Why?' 'Because she couldn't. She would rub her eyes, and go away and say she felt queer, and forget half of it and more, and then say it had been all a dream.' 'Just like me,' said Irene, feeling very much ashamed of herself. 'Yes, a good deal like you, but not just like you; for you've come again; and Lootie wouldn't have come again. She would have said, No, no--she had had enough of such nonsense.' 'Is it naughty of Lootie, then?' 'It would be naughty of you. I've never done anything for Lootie.' 'And you did wash my face and hands for me,' said Irene, beginning to cry.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: The elderly lady offered a gentle smile and spoke softly, 'I'm not upset with you, dear, nor with Lootie. However, I'd prefer if you didn't mention me to her anymore. If she inquires, just remain silent. Although, I doubt she'll ask.' Throughout their conversation, the elderly lady continued to spin. 'You haven't guessed what I'm spinning,' she remarked. 'That's because I don't know. It's quite lovely material.' Indeed, it was exquisite. Illuminated by the moonlight, the material on the spinning wheel gleamed like...how can I describe it? Not as bright as silver—yes, reminiscent of silver, but with a grayish hue rather than pure white, and only faintly sparkled. The thread she spun from it was so delicate that Irene could scarcely see it. 'I'm spinning this for you, my dear.' 'For me! What am I to do with it?' 'I'll explain later. But first, let me tell you what it is. It's spider silk—of a unique variety. My pigeons bring it to me from across the vast sea. There's only one forest where these spiders reside, producing the finest and strongest silk. I'm nearly finished with my current task. What's on the distaff now will suffice. Although,' she added, eyeing the bundle, 'I still have a week's worth of work ahead.'\n
output: The old lady smiled a sweet smile and said: 'I'm not vexed with you, my child--nor with Lootie either. But I don't want you to say anything more to Lootie about me. If she should ask you, you must just be silent. But I do not think she will ask you.' All the time they talked the old lady kept on spinning. 'You haven't told me yet what I am spinning,' she said. 'Because I don't know. It's very pretty stuff.' It was indeed very pretty stuff. There was a good bunch of it on the distaff attached to the spinning-wheel, and in the moonlight it shone like--what shall I say it was like? It was not white enough for silver--yes, it was like silver, but shone grey rather than white, and glittered only a little. And the thread the old lady drew out from it was so fine that Irene could hardly see it. 'I am spinning this for you, my child.' 'For me! What am I to do with it, please?' 'I will tell you by and by. But first I will tell you what it is. It is spider-web--of a particular kind. My pigeons bring it me from over the great sea. There is only one forest where the spiders live who make this particular kind--the finest and strongest of any. I have nearly finished my present job. What is on the rock now will be enough. I have a week's work there yet, though,' she added, looking at the bunch.

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: 'Do you work around the clock, great-great-great-great-grandmother?' inquired the princess, aiming to be exceptionally courteous with so many 'greats.' 'I'm not quite as ancient as all that,' she replied, smiling warmly. 'If you address me as grandmother, that will suffice. No, I don't toil every night—only when the moon is full, and even then, only as long as its light graces my spinning wheel. I won't be working much longer tonight.' 'And what do you do afterward, grandmother?' 'Retire to bed. Would you care to see my chamber?' 'Yes, I'd like that very much.' 'In that case, I'll cease my work for tonight. I'll be ready shortly.'\n
output: 'Do you work all day and all night, too, great-great-great-great-grandmother?' said the princess, thinking to be very polite with so many greats. 'I am not quite so great as all that,' she answered, smiling almost merrily. 'If you call me grandmother, that will do. No, I don't work every night--only moonlit nights, and then no longer than the moon shines upon my wheel. I shan't work much longer tonight.' 'And what will you do next, grandmother?' 'Go to bed. Would you like to see my bedroom?' 'Yes, that I should.' 'Then I think I won't work any longer tonight. I shall be in good time.'

instruction: Rephrase the following text with in the style of George MacDonald: The elderly woman stood up, leaving her spinning wheel untouched. There was no need to tidy up since there was no furniture to clutter the space. She then gently grasped Irene's hand, but it was her injured hand, causing Irene to let out a small cry of discomfort. 'My dear!' exclaimed her grandmother, 'what's wrong?'\n
output: The old lady rose, and left her wheel standing just as it was. You see there was no good in putting it away, for where there was not any furniture there was no danger of being untidy. Then she took Irene by the hand, but it was her bad hand and Irene gave a little cry of pain. 'My child!' said her grandmother, 'what is the matter?'
